definitions.definition: ( impersonal ) To have hailstones fall from the sky.
examples: They say it's going to hail tomorrow.

definitions.definition: ( intransitive ) To send or release hail .
examples: The cloud would hail down furiously within a few minutes.

definitions.definition: To pour down in rapid succession .

main_definition: ( impersonal ) To have hailstones fall from the sky.
secondary_definitions: ( intransitive ) To send or release hail .
To pour down in rapid succession .

definitions.definition: To greet ; give salutation to; salute .
To name ; to designate ; to call .
examples: He was hailed as a hero.

definitions.definition: To call out loudly in order to gain the attention of.

subdefinitions.definition: To indicate , from a designated stop or otherwise, to the driver of a public transport vehicle that one wishes to board and travel on the vehicle, usually using hand signals such as waving .
examples: In Melbourne, you would usually have to hail a tram when you are travelling late at night and there are no other passengers waiting at your stop.

definitions.definition: To signal in order to initiate communication with.
In the game of uppies and downies , to throw (the ball) repeatedly up and down at the goal location, in order to score a point.
to originate (from), be native (to) or be based (in)

main_definition: ( transitive ) To greet ; give salutation to; salute .
secondary_definitions: ( transitive ) To name ; to designate ; to call .
( transitive ) To call out loudly in order to gain the attention of.
( transitive ) To signal in order to initiate communication with.
( transitive ) In the game of uppies and downies , to throw (the ball) repeatedly up and down at the goal location, in order to score a point.
(from) to originate (from), be native (to) or be based (in)
